I enjoyed Clicker Heroes. I put a few months into the game. As of posting this, I have every achievement in the game (and on steam) except for 3400 and 3600. I'm on my final run, just passing 3260. I expect to be done with this game completely very soon. What clicker game will I play next?

Tap Tap Infinity has just the right amount of content, a well-balanced fairness to it regarding gems especially, and you progress pretty quickly, which is ideal for an incremental game. Also praise the left/right mouse clicking!

If you've played Cookie Clicker, AdVenture Capitalist, or Clicker Heroes and you enjoyed it at least a little bit, try this one out. If you like it, great! If you don't, you lose nothing.

reviewText:
A fun little time waster. My biggest problem with Clicker Heroes was that it took so much longer to get to Dread Knights than everything that came before them. I felt the curve there was unfair. I also didn't like how you had to choose between Ancients, and if you happened to get four you didn't want to choose from, then tough luck. Gilding heroes in Clicker Heroes is also random - it's possible to get a useless hero upgraded, and then you have to expend resources to fix it.

Tap Tap Infinity is very similar to Clicker Heroes, except it fixes those aspects of the game. There are 21 heroes to hire and upgrade, and they're all available very quickly. There are 4 Guardians with 4 skills each, and you always have access to all of them as long as you have enough infinity tokens to pay for the next level. There's even some semblance of a plot, to explain why the level design loops every 100 levels, and why the heroes are willing to fight for you. You can also upgrade your spells, which I don't remember whether you could in Clicker Heroes - I got too frustrated with the progression curve in that game to keep up with it. And when it comes to upgrading your heroes, you get to choose which ones to upgrade when.

Basically, this game is Clicker Heroes but trimmed down to exclude some of the fat, and improve on some of the weak points. It's streamlined. And it has 3d graphics. If you're looking for an idle game to pop in on when you have some time to kill, this is a good option.

reviewText:
It's funny to read reviews from people who have barely played the game calling it a knock-off. Fragsworth actually defended this game on Reddit when someone called it a clone. The differences become more apparent the longer you play, so give the game a chance if you are into the clicker/incremental genres. The Spells, Guardian powers, currencies etc. all function differently here than in Clicker Heroes and there are other unique features as well, with more constantly being added.

I've played the game since December on the web version and am currently on my second playthrough (reached the final level and hard reset in June). I even had the privilege to be made a boss in the game because of my contributions to the game's wiki. As I see it, TTI has numerous advantages over Clicker Heroes et al.:

First, the dev is amazing. He is reliable, reasonable and constantly interacts with the community to collect suggestions and feedback. Even if he rejects your idea, he'll explain why and is open to further discussion. Several of my suggestions have made it into the game and it's obvious he really values players' feedback, including often asking our opinions before implementing major updates, preventing some of the total update catastrophes that blight other games in the genre. He'll also help you swiftly if you lost your save or are experiencing bugs. Notably, he's even been interacting with the playerbase while he's on vacation! In short, he cares about the playerbase a lot.
Very frequent updates, and in particular a very swift turnaround on bug fixes and other things players are complaining about. He's always sharing what he's planning next and how the update is going so that it's not frustrating to wait.
In terms of the game design, Scarybee has worked really hard to make the game more convenient to play and I think this game is in the forefront of the genre for Quality of Life features, such as grid mode, round levelling to multiples of 25, and things like this which make the routine of playing the game a lot less frustrating.
As for pacing, balancing and things like that, I find this game overall a lot more consistent, intuitive and less frustrating than other games in the genre. You don't unlock things in a random order according to RNG, which can screw you over if you're unlucky; it's very hard to screw yourself over permanently by upgrading the wrong things, so there's no pressure to follow a strict guide for everything - go your own way! The pace is well-balanced, with very few walls, and even the walls that do exist are easily overcome with the right investments; the game is a lot more flexible in terms of strategy, unlike some games in the genre where you're pretty much forced to play one or two ways in order to make any progress. I feel therefore this game is a lot more accessible and less rigid than others in the genre.
However, there is a great deal of depth as well, particularly in stuff like the VP Upgrades, spell strategies and Ascension (which is a way of resetting rank to get more DPS, it's not like ascending in Clicker Heroes, which is called 'going infinite' here), so the game can appeal to casual players and min-maxers alike.
While there is a currency that can be bought with real money, it's also easily obtainable by F2P players as well (there are many guaranteed drops of Gems throughout the game) and it's not at all necessary to buy Gems to complete the game. You're not constantly bugged to buy Gems or anything, it's actually very easy to forget you can buy Gems with real money at all. You won't be crippled by being F2P because Scarybee cares about F2P players just as much as paying ones.
On that note, you also don't need to use an autoclicker or tap a ridiculous amount to progress in this game. The skills Conquest and Banking will give you big DPS and gold bonuses for idling, and with the Spell Monstrous Strength you'll be able to tap without breaking idle mode, which is excellent for Boss Rush (a spell where you skip all normal levels, only fighting bosses, which is really cool.) While Scarybee doesn't care if you use autoclickers, so you won't be penalised for using one (although it's not as beneficial as in other games like Realm Grinder, unless you use the autoclicker to level Heroes for you), he also hasn't scaled the game for autoclicker-users, which means people who choose not to use one won't be screwed over either. I think this is a really healthy balance which makes the game rewarding for everyone no matter the way you choose to play.
Long after I gave up on CH and Adcap, I'm still here playing TTI and I am really excited to see how the game continues to develop. If you're into the genre or interested in getting into the genre, give this game a chance!

One of my skills is rank 5, It will cost me 40k Infinity tokens which is really long to do, way too long, It's almost impossible.

+50%  Infinity Tokens: Immediately grants +50% of your lifetime Infinity tokens earned (xx.xx). Adds + xx.xx active tokens.
which cost 300 gems so approximately 22.00$.
Something like that doesn't even have a value of 0.25$ but for them Its value is 22$

reviewText: Hi all, pzratnog here. December 18th was the day I found this game. I had just lost my save file in clicker heros. I can't even begin to describe how lucky I was that that happened since losing my save is what brought me to tap tap infinity. Initially, I was pleasantly surprised by two factors in TTI - namely the cloud save and an active, polite, responsive developer. Players starting the game now benefit from dozens of features the game did not have when I started: spells, ascensions and ranks, valor point upgrades,grid mode for easy buying, multilevel buying, presents, and so many more. All or most of these features were added at least in part due to community feedback. The dev, ScaryBee, is truly fantastic about that kind of stuff. New features constantly are rolling out to keep the experience fresh. I've been playing 7 months now, been through the game 3 times, coded an optimizer (find it on the wiki), had a superboss named after me, and am still in love with this game mostly because of how great the dev is. Give it a go, and if you like incrimentals, I can almost guarantee this will quickly become one of your favorites!

reviewText:
Played this game sooo much on my phone and on the web. If you love idle games then this is a great game. It looks great, it's very well balanced, it doesn't rely heavily on random things happening to be able to progress. One huge thing that stands out for me is the ability to save to the cloud across all versions of the game, no matter what device you are on.

The dev is one of the best game devs I've ever spoke too, he's always active on the web version of the game talking to players in the chat, he is also very active on the TTI subreddit, he truly listens to player feedback and acts on it if he agrees very quickly. As well as the subreddit there is a wiki that is kept up to date with all the latest information, including a beginners guide for new players, both the subreddit and wiki conveniently have buttons in-game to take you directly to them.

If you love idle games then give this one a try, to me it is one of the best available with no paywall or unlucky RNG rolls that will stop your progress.

reviewText: Yet another step forward in the genre.  Yes, there are things in common with Clicker Heroes, but, guess what, a LARGE portion of Clicker Heroes was based on Cookie Clicker.  That's how games work.  Tap Tap Infinity, despite not having the best name ever, is an improvement on Clicker Heroes in many ways.  The main thing that is better in CH is that you can look at the ancient (guardians here) list while the game is running.  Also, in TTI you may hit a point where a paid currency is required to advance in one aspect, but I've not hit that yet.  I personally prefer the enemies in CH, but that's a soley a stylistic choice.  On the other hand, In TTI, you can actually advance, including clearing bosses, and receiving their respective loot, while offline.  The gifts are more powerful and varied here, but, because of this they are less common and you have to actually notice them.  There are quite a few mechanics, spells, and ancients different.  The rank system is solely TTI (YOU level up, as well as your heroes).  Graphics are better (obviously).  The grid display is a VAST improvement.\n\nTL;DR  If you think they're the same game, you've not played much of either.  If you like the genre, you'll VERY likely like TTI.  It's an actual step forward from CH, IMO, unlike all the other recent ones that feel more like side-steps.

reviewText:
Tap Tap Infinity is an incremental clicker/idle game.

Click to deal damage to enemies. Earn gold. Spend that gold on upgrades to your click damage. Purchase automatic damage over time, and upgrade that. Unlock special skills and use them to defeat enemies faster, or earn more gold per kill, and invest that gold into more upgrades so you can kill faster and get more gold to invest so you can kill faster and get more gold to invest so you can kill faster and get more gold to invest so you can kill faster and get more gold to invest so you can kill faster and get more gold to invest so you can kill faster and get more gold to invest...

Yep. It's one of these types of games. There's a prestige system that gives you a special currency that you can use to purchase various powerups that do a lot of things, such as decreasing skill cooldowns, increase gold dropped, increase dps.

To many people, this type of game seems boring. To those people, I'd suggest peeking at a few games like this to see what the appeal is. It's basically a distillation of most game genres that have some form of upgrade system, such as obtaining better gear or gaining levels and powerful perks.

Personally, I like these types of games. They satisfy that reward center in the brain. It's a perfect example of the Skinner Box.

It seems like a lot of comments don't understand this type of game.
I've played quite a few, mostly browser based instead of on Steam.

It's really not the kind of genre with new exciting things. It's an idling game.
You buy things and upgrade things in order to buy better things and better upgrades. There really isn't anything deeper than that. It's the kind of thing I play while rewatching stuff on netflix, or listening to music and podcasts. I tend to multitask online, not a good thing while listening to podcasts. Reading something and listening to people talk, and trying to pay equal attention to both... well, it doesn't work. And that's why I like this type of game. It's a fun thing to focus on.

reviewText:
Tap Tap Infinity is an incremental clicker/idle game.

Click to deal damage to enemies. Earn gold. Spend that gold on upgrades to your click damage. Purchase automatic damage over time, and upgrade that. Unlock special skills and use them to defeat enemies faster, or earn more gold per kill, and invest that gold into more upgrades so you can kill faster and get more gold to invest so you can kill faster and get more gold to invest so you can kill faster and get more gold to invest so you can kill faster and get more gold to invest so you can kill faster and get more gold to invest so you can kill faster and get more gold to invest...

Yep. It's one of these types of games. There's a prestige system that gives you a special currency that you can use to purchase various powerups that do a lot of things, such as decreasing skill cooldowns, increase gold dropped, increase dps.

To many people, this type of game seems boring. To those people, I'd suggest peeking at a few games like this to see what the appeal is. It's basically a distillation of most game genres that have some form of upgrade system, such as obtaining better gear or gaining levels and powerful perks.

Personally, I like these types of games. They satisfy that reward center in the brain. It's a perfect example of the Skinner Box.
